content.statement: aku-014-physical-examination is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Mesenteric-Ischemia that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding aku-014-physical-examination helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of aku-014-physical-examination include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of aku-014-physical-examination.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

early_phase.classic_finding: Pain out of proportion to physical examination

abdominal_exam.inspection: May appear normal; patient restless, writhing
abdominal_exam.auscultation: Bowel sounds initially normal or hyperactive, then diminishing
abdominal_exam.palpation: Soft, non-tender or only mildly tender

vital_signs.respiratory_rate: May be elevated due to pain

early_phase.diagnostic_challenge: Examination may falsely reassure if disease not considered

abdominal_bruit.characteristics: Systolic, may be absent in complete occlusion

abdominal_exam.palpation: Non-tender between episodes; may have epigastric tenderness

findings.abdominal_exam: Tenderness may be less pronounced early
findings.bloody_stool: May occur earlier than arterial ischemia

findings.feeding_intolerance: High gastric residuals, inability to advance feeds

elderly.key_point: Lower threshold for imaging in elderly with unexplained deterioration

immunocompromised.findings: May lack fever, leukocytosis, peritoneal signs

challenges: Often on analgesics affecting pain report
post_operative.key_point: Have high suspicion after cardiac, aortic surgery

clinical_pearls.pearl: 'Pain out of proportion to examination' is the classic clue but present in only ~75% of early AMI cases
clinical_pearls.implication: Absence doesn't exclude diagnosis; don't wait for this sign in high-risk patients

clinical_pearls.pearl: The transition from soft abdomen to peritonitis marks the progression from reversible ischemia to transmural necrosis
clinical_pearls.implication: Serial examinations can track disease progression but must not delay definitive imaging/treatment

clinical_pearls.pearl: An abdominal bruit in a patient with unexplained weight loss and postprandial pain should prompt mesenteric duplex or CTA
clinical_pearls.implication: Physical finding that should trigger further workup

clinical_pearls.pearl: In ICU patients, abdominal distension and feeding intolerance may be the only signs of developing NOMI
clinical_pearls.implication: Maintain high vigilance in patients on vasopressors, post-cardiac surgery

inspection.key_point: Scaphoid abdomen suggests chronicity with malnutrition

auscultation.technique: Listen in all four quadrants before palpation
auscultation.bruits: Epigastric bruit suggests mesenteric stenosis (low sensitivity)

palpation.technique: Start away from area of maximal pain; superficial then deep

findings.blood: Gross blood or guaiac-positive stool suggests mucosal necrosis
findings.timing: Blood is a late finding—its presence indicates significant injury

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
